segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Hello, everyone. Thanks for coming. I'm Alex Frelos, and I'm joined by my colleague here,
Jack Butler, and we're presenting on COVID-19 tracing apps, the proliferation of rush development.
Now a little bit about ourselves. I'm currently a director at
a Fortune 500 company directing a penetration testing team. I'd like to consider myself
technical as well as managerial. Some of my interests lie in web application testing,
aviation testing, and just enjoying the outdoors. And my name is John Butler. I'm a mobile application
security specialist, and I have a strong background in prevention of reverse engineering of mobile
applications. I also currently work as a mobile app security specialist for a leading security
firm in the mobile space, Guard Square. And much of the research that we'll be presenting today,
as well as the findings that we'll discuss today, was conducted as part of my daily duties
and research alongside my peers over at Guard Square.
So to get things kicked off, we're going to actually go over a brief overview of what we
hope to accomplish during this conversation and just give you guys a little bit more of a backdrop
and some context to work off of. So the first thing we want to cover is the actual purpose
of today's conversation and the purpose of contact tracing applications in general.
For anybody here who doesn't know what a contact tracing application is,
it's meant to actually trace individuals who do or do not have COVID. But more importantly,
LERT users are specific individuals that are using the application of potential exposures to other
users that are within a proximal location. Now, just in order to address rollout history,
COVID-19 contact tracing applications have started to appear since the actual pandemic began.
We've seen a number of different changes over the course of time with regards to the tools
that are available in order to actually build security in to core functionality of these
applications. And we'll discuss this during our conversation here today as well.
We're also going to be touching upon different application variants. So something that you're
going to notice is that there are many different COVID-19 contact tracing applications, not one
unified application of any sort. So we see this is actually occurring on country-by-country basis,
but also state levels within the United States, adding to the confusion of which
one do you actually download. We're going to be touching on the importance of trust today. It's
a very important thing. If COVID-19 contact tracing applications are going to be adopted
and used as a effective utility for fighting this pandemic, then users need to trust that
the applications are built with security and privacy in mind. And we're going to be talking
users need to trust that the applications are built with security and privacy in mind.
And these are some of the contingencies that we'll also discuss today.
Moving on to just information collected by the application, we're going to, of course, be diving
into our findings on a very granular level, the controls that we analyzed within the applications,
the apps themselves, information that was collected by the applications that we view to be an overstep
and more. And that really ties into and folds nicely into our final point here, which is just
brokenness of COVID-19 contact tracing applications, many of the security and
privacy concerns that we've observed and recommendations for how we can improve in the
future. So now that we've provided a general overview of what we're going to be discussing
today and what we hope to accomplish in today's conversation, we can actually move on to a
general overview of our testing approach. So to help you better understand our testing
approach, we're going to be going over together the apps that we analyzed, as well as the actual
overview of controls studied. So the actual protection mechanisms that we were looking
for inside of these applications. And then we're also going to review a summary of findings
and an overview of the data that we were able to collect and analyze as a result of this research.
The first thing I would like to do is provide you with a timeline of the actual applications
that we analyzed so that you can better understand the entire backdrop of the research and the story
that goes behind it. So back in June of 2020, I actually had the opportunity to analyze 14 of the
original COVID-19 applications. Now at the time, these were actually just APKs, so the data was
limited to Android. This was certainly enough to pique interest in the privacy and security
concerns that reside in the space and definitely made myself, my colleagues, very interested to
see how this would progress into the future. So in December of 2020, myself and my colleagues
analyzed the same 14 original APKs that we took a look at. We extended that by taking a look at
another 38 Android applications. And we also extended the data set by introducing 43 new
iOS contact tracing applications to provide some telemetry there. So in general, and to provide a
real breakdown, we analyzed 95 applications in total. The majority of these were government
orchestrated contact tracing applications. But it's actually important to note that they
weren't all countries, so it's not just country by country. We actually do have 13 U.S. states
as well as two U.S. territories. So there were many different applications, and this actually adds to
some of the confusion behind finding the correct application and the opportunity behind
the phishing campaigns that we've observed, which we'll discuss later throughout this conversation.
Now for anybody interested in a more granular spread of what applications we actually took a
look at, I've gone ahead and I've enumerated all of those applications on this slide
here. So you can see both Android and iOS, the applications by country, by name, or by state and
name, U.S. territory and name. So you can actually take a closer look at all the different individual
applications that we analyzed as part of this presentation, as part of this analysis that we're
discussing here today. Now I'd like to start by providing a brief introduction on the Exposure
Notifications API, which was created by Apple and Google back in May of 2020. I've provided a link
to the developer documentation for anybody who's interested in taking a peek at this, and this is
actually created in order to unify the way in which application developers go about creating
secure contact tracing applications, and specifically was designed with a couple goals in mind, so
security, privacy, and safety. So safely and securely notify individuals of potential exposures to COVID-19,
but also to actually reduce and limit the collection of private user information, which
simply isn't necessary but was also observed in the existence of early COVID-19 contact tracing
applications. Now the implementation of this API is very simple. It's a secure Bluetooth
implementation. It doesn't collect any other information at all, and if you're actually
interested in learning more about how this works, you can take a look at the link that I've provided
here, though it is very simple, straightforward, and this won't be the primary point of the conversation
that we drive here today. Now as we discussed on the previous slide, the Exposure Notification API
had a couple goals in mind, and tying into that slide, we're going to discuss a little bit more in
depth what the expectations of this API were when it was created, and then what the actual outcomes
and the actual results that we observed in the wild are. So hopping into the actual expectations,
Google and Apple clearly had expected that by providing core functionality for developers to
actually make secure contact tracing applications using this secure Bluetooth mechanism that they
provided in this very convenient API that health organizations and the majority of the world
would actually adopt the API and use it. Of course, as mentioned, the API's goal is to provide
that core functionality for building secure applications. Providing this API was a major
innovation, and going back to trust, it's very important that users who download COVID-19
contact tracing applications can actually trust that those applications are secure
and that they're private. So Google and Apple genuinely possess the belief that
by designing applications with security and privacy top of mind, customers or users rather
who consume those applications will see value, they will trust those applications, and it will
actually drive the utility of contact tracing applications in helping prevent the spread of this
disease. Now, in terms of the applications that we analyzed in the subset of data that we're
discussing today, of the applications we analyzed, 60% of those apps did indeed use the exposure
notification API provided by Google and Apple. So 62% of Android applications and 58% of iOS
applications. However, 40% neglected to use the exposure notification API, and they instead took
a do-it-yourself approach to security. They completely neglected the core functionalities
provided to them by Google and Apple. And in many cases, there are actually these applications,
several of them that we analyzed are collecting unnecessary additional pieces of user information,
which we'll cover in later slides. So suffice it to say there were significant security and privacy
concerns, specifically within the 40% of applications that did not use the exposure
notifications API. And this is going to be the main focus and center of our conversation today.
So as opposed to focusing on the 60% of apps, which actually did use the exposure notification
API, we're actually going to be zooming in on the 40%, which deliberately elected not to use that.
So finally, with regards to our testing approach, I would like to actually cover the individual
controls studied and the actual security mechanisms that we tried to take a look at with regards to
the individual applications that we analyzed. So I have gone ahead and actually listed the
individual features that we were looking for in these individual applications. And I'll actually
take some time in order to discuss each of these features, their importance, the value add, and
we can go from there. So starting at the top with string encryption, it's very important to utilize
string encryption to replace sensitive contexts that might reveal secure operations inside of the
application. Now a perfect example of this that we see in applications very regularly is API endpoints.
API endpoints can be, and other sensitive strings, can be returned through reflection and can
otherwise appear throughout the application as well. It's very important to replace any of these
strings with encrypted representations that are entropy-less, that are meaningless, so that
attackers cannot easily enumerate these using tools like BoxMolly, using tools like the native
Unix command strings, or others like Redari as well. Now name obfuscation is a very basic feature.
It is provided by open source optimization tools such as ProGuard, but it is really
only designed to modify the names of common identifiers of classes, methods, fields, and things
of the sort. That said, it still adds a level of complexity to your application so that when
attackers do disassemble your code, the package structure and the names of classes, methods, fields,
and things of that sort are not immediately obvious. Now data at rest encryption is very
important if you do have sensitive files or sensitive information that is stored in, for
example, SQLite files. Those should, of course, be encrypted at rest. Otherwise, what
you're actually going to find is that those files are effectively unencrypted, and this is something
that we did notice in a number of the COVID contact tracing applications is that they do
collect sensitive information that's not necessary. They do store it completely unencrypted, and
these are some of the privacy concerns that we'll discuss later.
Moving on to RASP, which stands for Runtime Application Self-Protection,
these are also known as resiliency features. So if you adhere to a security framework such as
the Mobile Application Security Verification Standard by OWASP, you can actually take a look
at the Mobile Security Testing Guide. What you're going to find in there is that there
are resilience guidelines. These resilience guidelines are specifically aimed to help
organizations implement robust security controls to protect their applications both statically
and dynamically against online and offline attacks. Now we are really going to be taking a look at two
features in particular. That's going to be root detection and jailbreak detection. So those are
the equivalent feature on either platform, Android and iOS. And of course, these forms
of runtime checks are going to ensure at all entry points in the application that if it is opened,
ideally, it should crash on a jailbroken or a rooted Android device.
Similarly, emulator checks are designed in order to ensure that if the application is executed on
an emulated device, for example, ADB, it will crash inside of that emulated environment.
So we'll actually take a look at this. We'll see how many applications actually did use
robust controls like this and how many didn't. And we're also going to be taking a look at SSL
pinning. SSL pinning is very important to secure communications and information traveling over the
wire between the application and a backend. So if you are serializing inputs, if you are sending
sensitive information over the wire, it's very, very important to actually pin your application
to its backend, either using a certain number of public keys or certificates. And it's also
very important to further secure those implementations so that they cannot later be
patched out, which is very common. Finally, we have arrived at app attestation. App attestation
just allows for the possibility of actually distinguishing that the application itself
is receiving a legitimate connection from the application or from an instance of that
application itself. So a great example of this is Google Safety Net. And this is just one of
the many things that we did take a look at inside of the applications that we analyzed.
So with this in mind, we're now going to move on to an overview of the
data that we gathered and summarize some of those results for you.
So now that we've explained our testing approach and our methodology, we're going to go into
a full overview of the data and the analysis that we actually performed,
as well as the takeaways that we were able to derive from analyzing that data.
So hopping directly into the data, you can actually see here on our first slide,
we are taking a look at the Android applications. Now, of all of the 40% of applications that fell
into the category which did not use the exposure notification API, we did take a look at 20
do-it-yourself Android applications. And of them, we have actually mapped the different percentage
of those applications that adhered to the controls that we were looking for
and possessed these different protection mechanisms. And it's very clear that on the
Android side of the house, most applications don't possess these protections and therefore
additionally possess weak security posture.
Piggybacking off the last slide, you can see on this slide that we provided a number of
applications and a percentage of applications which adhere to the control mechanisms that
we took a look at on the previous slide. So for example, you can actually see that 95%
of these applications possess two or fewer of the protections that we were looking at.
Now, please do bear in mind that the slide that we're reviewing right now is just the
Android portion of the applications that we looked at. But just from a 30,000-foot view
of the 40% of applications that we analyzed which did not use the exposure notification API,
95% of those applications used two or fewer protections, meaning they're not building
these applications with security or privacy in mind. And actually, zero of them had five
or more of these protections.
So now taking a look at the iOS side of the house, you can see that we have equivalently
provided the same control mechanisms that we looked at for the Android side. And in
the top right-hand corner, you're going to see that for the iOS side of the house, we
actually analyzed 18 do-it-yourself iOS applications. By do-it-yourself, we mean these applications
deliberately elected not to use the exposure notification API and instead elected to implement
controls themselves.
Now, what you can see is that most of these features are actually implemented very
conservatively across the applications that we analyzed. And actually, app attestation
and name obfuscation just simply don't appear at all. So once again, on the iOS side of
the house, we are very quickly realizing that robust security does not seem to exist inside
of the majority of these contact tracing applications.
And now, once again, you can see that we have provided the same chart that we did for
Android in order to display the number of applications and the percentage of applications
which actually adhered to a certain number of the controls that we were looking for.
So in this case, we can actually see that 61% of the iOS applications that we looked
at, so 11 of the 18, actually possessed two or fewer controls. And in general, 94% of
these applications possessed two or less. So on the Android side, we can see that 95%
of those applications. And on the iOS side, we can see that 94% of those applications
possessed two or fewer of the controls that we were looking for.
Once again, representing that these COVID app contact tracing applications are not
being built with security in mind.
Now, beyond the lack of security controls, which we were able to highlight in previous
slides, we also believe that privacy concerns should be a large portion of today's conversation
and should be illuminated. So we're going to take a look at GPS privacy concerns, which
we observed in a number of these different contact tracing applications. And we're going
to start by calling out the fact that many GPS apps or a number of the GPS apps that
we observed actually collect additional user information, which is not necessary, such
as a passport number, phone number, a device ID, or other pieces of valuable information
which aren't required to anonymously notify users of potential exposure. Additionally,
those sensitive pieces of information were, in some cases, stored in securely, such as
in unencrypted SQL-like databases, or potentially leaked in other ways, making them effectively
unencrypted. So it's very safe to say that this is definitely a privacy concern. These
applications actually don't need to collect additional information, which is the point
of the exposure notification API, which only relies on Bluetooth and does not collect any
other sensitive pieces of user information. And with that being said, this can actually
call into question the safety of these applications and potentially hinder the value
of contact tracing applications when it comes to combating the pandemic itself.
So in summarizing the results, there was a gross lack of static protection amongst the
applications that we analyzed. And you were able to very clearly see that based on the data in the
previous slides, based on the controls that we looked at in the very low percentage of
applications that actually contained those. Similarly, the runtime protections were poorly
implemented. And in most cases, and in many cases, they were just not implemented at all,
meaning that both static reverse engineering of applications, disassembling and understanding
code, making changes to that code would be very feasible and trivial for attackers.
Exploitation at runtime, so whether it be attaching debuggers, opening it on a rooted or
an emulated device, modifying and tampering with files, hooking functions and things of that sort,
once again, would all be very easy at runtime. We also noticed exposed API endpoints, which
makes data in transit a concern. As we mentioned, several of these applications are not only
collecting GPS information, but also sensitive user information. And if you're not implementing
SSL pinning, which most of these applications certainly were not, then data in transit is
a concern. And even if you do implement SSL pinning, if you don't have the robust protections,
both static and dynamic needed to secure those implementations and prevent attackers from just
patching them out either statically or at runtime by, for example, hooking those functions,
then once again, these SSL pinning implementations will simply be bypassed.
So returning to the first two points, the lack of static and dynamic protection
is a large concern, which leads to greater issues. String encryption, for example,
would be able to very easily encrypt the strings or the API endpoints, very quickly mitigating
this risk. Finally, we were able to identify multiple different instances of rogue applications.
So in our sources, we have provided links to a number of different cases of rogue applications
that are floating under the veil of COVID-19 legitimate governing bodies and applications
for users. But in actuality, they're masquerading as those legitimate sources,
hoping that unsuspecting victims will download and install their rogue application and grant
them permissions into either their Android or iOS device. Now, we've also seen instances of
ransomware appearing, once again, under the veil of COVID-19. So you can see CryDroid
instances that have occurred. So this is something to bear in mind. Once again, if these
governing bodies are not hardening their applications, then it's very easy for
attackers to very quickly modify them and use them as portions of phishing campaigns
that can be used to actually stage more sophisticated attacks downstream.
Some other observations that we made throughout our testing and research
was, first of all, that application security is not determined by nation's wealth. So for example,
if we look at Israel, who's number 32 out of 196 in terms of GDP in the year 2020, they had
significantly worse application security than some of the countries in Africa who had their own
contact tracing app. Now, that's contrary to what we thought. We thought that a country who had high
GDP had a lot of money for developing a contact tracing app securely, but that's not the case.
Second of all, GDPR and HIPAA violations were noticed, especially in the DIY apps.
England's was one. Their test and trace program broke GDPR data laws because they weren't adhering
to GDPR regulations as it pertained to the storage and processing of data.
Now, thirdly, there's the encouragement of waiving data privacy rights. There are users who are
downloading these applications thinking that they're robust with security and privacy in mind,
but that's not the case. So there needs to be transparency, and there wasn't in terms of
how privacy was being handled. Let's move on to flawed development and integration.
We clearly noticed that development teams were having difficulties in a variety of areas.
The first of them being timeline sensitivity. With the pandemic picking up in pace,
development had to be rushed to get a working application out as soon as possible. The sprints,
as a result, were focused on fixing functionality or creating that functionality,
leaving little consideration for security in that time.
The second thing we noticed was that the development team had to choose between
their approach to constraints, whether they wanted quality, which would require a long
development time, or if they wanted short release time, but as a result, control the spread and
potentially save human lives. The third difficulty that we saw these development teams have was the
fact that this was such a unique solution. There hadn't been a contact tracing app before that
had to be released on such a large scale. There was no previous poster child. I don't think that
a developer could go on to Stack Overflow and get the necessary code and call it a day.
That wasn't really possible there. The fact that these applications were handling sensitive data,
this had to be looked at in terms of privacy. Some applications, of course, considered privacy
and security very well, others didn't, but either way, there had to be some sort of
consideration for that sensitive data, even at minimum.
The rush to development of these contact tracing applications didn't come without any effects.
There's actually quite a few effects that came about as a result.
As I mentioned in the last slide, there was a main focus on functionality of the applications
and a limited regard for security and privacy as a result, just mainly because the goal was
to develop an application as soon as possible and release it to the public. Furthermore, there was a
lacking of features that would allow for integration with other apps or COVID apps.
Let's say the European Union wanted all of Europe's countries to be able to use the app,
the European Union wanted all of Europe's countries to integrate into one application.
This wouldn't be possible because this integration feature wasn't built in. However, as a result,
less time was spent on development, which means that getting to the controlling of the spread
happened sooner. You can claim that as a benefit. Lastly, there was an ethical dilemma.
These developers know that there's a known risk of security in these applications, yet
they're still releasing it. The question is, do you release an app that is unhardened due to lack
of time and money? On one hand, the spread might be thwarted, but at the same time, it's opening
doors for a long-term headache if these people's data get stolen. You have to weigh the long-term
effects against the short-term in that case. Let's move on to recommendations for timebox
development. The first recommendation is to unify apps. That can be done in one of two ways,
or both. The first being using a common API, and the second being consolidating apps. The first way
is using one of Google's or Apple's APIs, also known as the Notification Exposure API, or similar.
I put an asterisk there because I believe that it doesn't necessarily have to be a private company
solution. It could be a public government-created solution. Either way, global issues should be
fought on a global scale. There should be that common API that should be utilized when it's
there. The second, as I mentioned, is consolidating apps. There are way too many apps on the app
stores. Users have trouble knowing which one's legitimate, which one's not. The fact that there
are so many state-level apps, that's just contributing to the issue. To that, we're
just saying, no, let's skip not having these state-level apps. Country is fine, but making
sure that it's utilizing the common API and not a do-it-yourself one. Anybody who's not
complying with this, our thoughts are that they should be fined. There's going to be proposed
contact tracing app requirements, and anybody who's not adhering to them should be fined.
The second thing we'd like to recommend is a security-focused SDLC. For those of you who
aren't familiar with what an SDLC is, it's a software development life cycle. It's typically
found in companies and pertains to how development goes from start to finish. We're particularly
recommending a shift-left approach, which means including security earlier and at every phase,
meaning that it's everywhere, and that it's a forethought, not an afterthought.
We're recommending that teams aren't siloed. If there's a security team, we want them to work
with a development team for communication to be facilitated. There doesn't have to be a
pick-one approach to choosing either functionality or security. You can have both. That's the fact
that these development and security teams can work in parallel together, especially when new
features are being released. There could be an iterative approach where security is constantly
being checked in these features. One thing that would allow for security tests in these types of
feature releases is something called a technical security review, which documents that there's
been scanning in the code that's been performed, documents the inter-service communication.
The service has to communicate with another service. That will be documented there,
along with any scanning results, testing that had been done.
If there is no software development lifecycle, in the case that a company doesn't have to adhere to
PCI regulations or HIPAA, what have you, then typically you can hook it into an existing
change management process. You can hook security processes into that because whenever there's an
application that gets added to an inventory, let's say, typically there's a change management process
for that. Very similarly, you can just include security aspects to be included in that.
Now, with regards to development requirements, we have a number of recommendations that we
would provide, starting with adhering to some form of security standard or security framework
like OWASP. You can take a closer look at, for example, OWASP Mobile Application Security
Verification Standard or the Mobile Security Testing Guide, which both will act as an excellent
blueprint for security specialists that are looking to implement robust controls inside of
their mobile applications. And then also, as mentioned in the second point here, add resilience
to that application so that it can stand up to and defend itself from sophisticated attackers,
both statically and dynamically. Now, we also recommend employing a masked scanning solution
so that you can identify vulnerabilities in code and actually remediate those.
And we also then recommend implementing a code hardening solution. So, as we were able to
illuminate earlier and identify most of the applications we're taking a look at here don't
have any form of obfuscation, string encryption, runtime application self-protection mechanisms,
or other basic security components which would be useful in deterring bad actors. So,
by employing a code hardening solution, you can make it infeasible for those attackers who
are actually looking to make modifications and nefariously attack those applications.
And lastly, we hope that the final product through these recommendations will be a more
safe and secure privacy-focused application that earns the trust of its users and overall
results in improved adoption and utility in combating this pandemic.
Now, on the previous slide, we recommended a code hardening solution. And the reason for this is
that in all fairness and in our honest experience, we can tell you that most teams, while
they do have what's needed to build a functional application, don't have what they need to implement
robust security controls. In fact, most development teams are focused on functionality and performance
of that application. But it's very important to consider that these government bodies
who should actually be employing robust security controls to protect their user base
should be using a code hardening solution. Code hardening solutions, like some of the ones that
I'm about to recommend, will actually allow you to implement robust security controls in a very
short amount of time. More than that, what I can say is that as most of these security teams don't
possess in-house specialization in the area, they don't have the manpower to keep up with
the evolving threat landscape. So just the updates with Magisk and check rain and jailbreaking
routing of devices alone can be a very mighty task for development teams to manage. This is why by
outsourcing this type of work to a specialist firm or an actual enterprise-grade solution,
you can receive all the benefits of those protections and you can actually get wonderful
support when you need it. It'll all be maintained for you and you can really just focus on
implementing the features which are necessary as opposed to managing security, which quite frankly,
most of these governing bodies are woefully unprepared to do. So getting into the actual
meat and potatoes of today's slide besides the why for code protection, I think that's clear.
These governing bodies need to harden their code. They need to protect the sensitive user
data if they're going to collect it in the first place, which they shouldn't be.
And regardless, they need to earn the trust of their user bases to further drive adoption.
So with that in mind, to provide an agnostic recommendation, again, and you can look up
different code hardening solutions, I highly recommend GuardSquare. GuardSquare is the
leader in mobile application protection, offering code hardening solutions, both obfuscation and
encryption, runtime application self-protection, real-time threat event monitoring, and
application scanning solutions for both iOS, Android, Unity, and hybrid applications alike.
So if you are operating on a mobile platform, I highly recommend reaching out to GuardSquare,
scheduling a demo. You can feel free to reach out to me. And with that in mind, we can actually
help you address not only your pain points, but how we can help you address those pain points by
implementing robust security controls. Now, tying into the topic of the previous
slide in code hardening, really folding into this, is the idea and the importance of actually
adopting the triple constraint. And the triple constraint is the idea of balancing time, cost,
and quality. But in practice, we often find that you really many times can only pick two.
So I think this pandemic situation really underscored a perfect use case whereby they
just didn't have enough time. They rushed applications to market. They didn't put
money into specialized security knowledge or enterprise-grade code hardening solutions that
really could help implement these solutions. And as a result, they really suffered in the
quality department. If they had implemented security properly and actually standardized
the way they went about things from the right, from the get-go, if they had employed the correct
specialists in order to do this, then they really wouldn't have had these problems. But
it comes down to the fact that they haven't spent money on these solutions
in order to fix the problem correctly. The second thing that's important to acknowledge
is that it's not always just a matter of time or money. It's a matter of skill.
And so with that in mind, it's very important to accept the fact that many teams don't have
the specialized in-house knowledge for security. They're development teams. And that's totally fine.
Development is one thing. Security is a completely another thing. And it's completely fine to
outsource this and to buy an SDK that allows you to properly secure your mobile application.
Developers buy SDKs all the time for the purpose of saving time and not having to put specialists
into actually designing that thing. So really, security should not be viewed differently.
If you don't have the knowledge to implement it yourself, you should purchase the solution
from somebody else or at least governing bodies who are producing what are supposed to be
legitimized applications that are safe and secure for users. They should be doing this.
And lastly, it's very important to avoid the do-it-yourself scenario as much as possible,
because we're finding that most of the time, sophisticated attackers find a way to bypass that.
So if you don't have a solution that is backed by research and is tested in many environments,
then attackers are going to very quickly bypass that do-it-yourself implementation
using instrumentation tools and other methods. And it's really not going to get you very far.
So with this in mind, it's advisable to once again, use a code hardening solution,
especially in the event that you don't have a specialization. In many cases,
it's a whole lot cheaper than employing a bunch of specialists to do it in-house.
But also, the solution will be managed for you. You can get support. And in many times,
it just equates to less effort in that sense as well. If you enjoyed the topic of this presentation,
we'd like to recommend some ideas for future projects that you can take on yourself.
Quite simply, vaccine passport applications. They're very similar to contact tracing
applications, but they've had more development time as they're not time-pressed in terms of
development as they're racing against the surging pandemic. They're also more unified,
meaning that a whole region such as the European Union is only relying on one application versus
a multitude. But there's still a reason to be skeptical because we've seen the way that
the development approach has been for the contact tracing applications. Despite there being more
